existing_custody_order.reasoning: Complaint alleges an Existing Order entered Sept. 15, 2018 awarding Petitioner primary physical custody and limiting Respondent to short weekday visits and one Sunday afternoon visit with no overnights (¶¶2.1–2.2).

specific_modification_sought.reasoning: Complaint requests allowing Respondent overnight parenting time and proposes a specific framework (every-other-weekend Fri–Sun overnights, possible weeknight overnights, exchange/transport arrangements) while seeking Court flexibility to adopt an appropriate schedule (¶¶5.1–5.2, 4.2, Prayer ¶7).

material_substantial_change.reasoning: Complaint alleges factual changes since the 2018 order: Respondent now has his own apartment with a separate bedroom (¶3.2(a)); the child is older (3 → 8) and attends school full time with different needs (¶3.2(b)); the current short-visit schedule causes disruption to school/homework and logistical strain (¶3.2(c)); and the parties agree a change is appropriate (¶3.2(d)). These facts tie to the circumstances underlying the original no-overnight restriction and are pleaded as substantial and material (¶3.3, Prayer ¶7.1(a)).

best_interests_of_child.reasoning: Complaint alleges the requested modification serves the child's best interests by honoring Daniel's expressed desire for sleepovers, providing a safe sleeping environment at Respondent's apartment, reducing disruption/fatigue from current shuttling which harms schooling and routines, promoting meaningful contact with both parents, and proposing safeguards (gradual introduction, monitoring, status hearings) to protect welfare (¶6.1–6.2; ¶3.2(a)–(c); ¶5.2).
